components.text: In this tutorial, you will learn how to deploy your own version of this website. This tutorial will teach you how to deploy using Heroku, which is a very straight-forward service, very easy to use and FREE! You will also use GitHub, to download the website to your account and to upload the website to Heroku.
This tutorial will only talk about deploying with Heroku. If you want to deploy your website on a local server, check the Github description page for the website linked below.

This tutorial will also teach you how to use the various tools available on the website to edit its content. You can use the admin features to create your own version of content, embed links, images, videos and all sorts of components with minimal effort.

list_elements.text: In this chapter, we will simply create a Heroku and a Github account. These tools will be needed in order to download the website to your Github account and upload it to Heroku, which is a cloud server that will make your website available for other users to see for FREE!

components.text: First, you will need a Github account. Go to their website(linked in the name) and create an account. This is a simple process resembling all other sign-up forms you have probably used before.
Once you have created the account, you should login. Your landing page will look something like this.
You can read the guide for a bit to understand what github does, but for the purpose of this tutorial, it is not necessary.
We will do the same with Heroku. Create an account and then log in.
The landing page will look something like this.
You can click the 'New' Button and then 'Create New App'. This will prompt you to the second screen which looks like this.
The name you choose will be the name of you website. For example, if you choose test-server-2018, then the name of your website will be https://test-server-2018.herokuapp.com

Try to have your Github and Heroku accounts set up. In Heroku, you can also create your new app at this point and name it however you want.
These are necessities in order to continue to the next chapter.
In this chapter, you will do all the necessary work to upload and start your website on your heroku server.

list_elements.text: Learn how to fork a repository on Github.
Learn how to link your github repository to your heroku app.
Learn how to deploy your website using heroku.

components.text: In github, every user can have repositories. These can be private and public. A repository is a collection of files, that is stored on the cloud. Github also comes with a version control system, meaning that the state of your files is saved between changes. This means that you can see previous versions of your files after you have made changes. In our context, this can be useful if you have made mistakes when editing the content of the website and want to revert back to a previous state.

This website is available in the format of a github repository. You can find it here. In order to continue at this point, you need to get a copy of this repository into your own github account. In order to do that, there is a process in github called forking a repository.

In order to complete this step, you need to fork a copy of the website template page into your own github account. Simply go to this repository and click the 'Fork' button on the top-right side. This process will take several seconds, and then you will end up with a repository in your github account that has the name 'ifs-template-website'.
You now have a repository in your github account called 'ifs-template-website'. Congratulations!!
The next step is letting our heroku app know where our repository is.

list_elements.text: Go to your dashboard and select the previously created heroku app.
Go to the 'Deploy' tab
Where it says 'Deployment Method', click on Github.
Below that, there is a form with the title 'Search for a repository to connect to'. Start typing the name of your repository, which should be 'ifs-template-website' if you haven't changed the name.
Once you click 'Search', the results will show just below. Click 'Connect' on the search result that pops up.

After you connect the repository to heroku, more options will appear on the screen. You don't have to worry about these. Simply scroll all the way down to the section labelled 'Manual Deploy' and then click the button 'Deploy Branch'.

After you click the button, the repository is copied on the heroku server. This takes some time, but you are provided feedback in the logs below. Once this process is done, another button will pop up , the 'View' button. Clicking this will take you to your new website.

components.text: You have done a lot of work in this chapter, and you now have a brand new website ready and deployed. It is time now to take a look at how to protect its admin features so that you are the only one that can access them. Let's talk about Authentication.

The admin page of this website lets you edit the entire content of the website, and the button to access it is available from the top bar. The admin page has been exposed in such way to make it easier for you and other content creators to access it.

Because it is so exposed, there are a couple of authentication methods available to restrict access to it. If you opt for any of the authentication methods, you can better protect the content of the website.
None of the two authentication methods are mandatory, but it is highly advised to include at least the local authentication.

list_elements.text: To explain how local authentication works and how to set it up
To learn how to set up github authentication and how to use it.

components.text: The username and password for the admin features are stored in environment variables.
To create these on a local server, there are instructions on the template's github repository.
To do this on Heroku, follow these steps:

list_elements.text: Open your app from your dashboard
Go to the Settings Tab
Click on Reveal Config Vars

You must enter two variables, one for the username, one for the password.
There is a KEY field and a VALUE field and a button ADD.
For the username, enter USERNAME in the key field (must be all caps) and in the value field enter your desired username and click ADD.
For the password, enter PASSWORD in the key field (must be all caps) and in the value field enter your desired password and click ADD.

components.text:
You have now set up some authentication for your website.
Try to access the admin page now and if everything is all right, you should be prompted to enter these variables. 
You now have a secure admin page!
Will come in the future.
In this chapter, I will go over the admin page, its structure and elements and try to get you familiar with all the various components that are available, how to add and remove them.

list_elements.text: Learn the terminology.
Explore the various widgets and buttons available on the admin page.
Explore the Undo queue and learn how to correct mistakes.
Learn how to add and remove elements.
Explore the available components in small detail.

chapters.name: Getting to grips with page structure

components.subtitle: Blocks
components.text: Blocks are the main elements of your data. They encapsulate all chapters and are available in the navigation menu on the left. The blocks in this case are: Introduction, Getting the website running, Authentication etc.
Blocks are made of chapters. Below there is an example of blocks.

components.subtitle: Chapters
components.text: Chapters are the containers inside a block. For example, the chapters for the 'Admin Primer' block are : Introduction, Getting to grips with page structure, Adding and removing elements, etc. See below an example of chapters in the block Admin Primer

components.subtitle: Sections
components.text: Each page is made of several sections. A section starts with a coloured title. Sections also appear on the right side navigation menu for quick navigation. An example of a section can be seen below
It is good practice to give your Blocks, Chapters and Sections very relevant names, as they appear in navigation menus and allow the user to quickly navigate to what they are looking for

components.subtitle: Components
components.text: Everything else is a component. All paragraphs, images, videos, alerts, links are components. When you create a page, it will usually be several sections which contain several components. We will go over components more in a later chapter. An example of some components can be seen below.
The main menu on the left contains all the Blocks and Chapters, while the menu on the right will display all sections on the currently selected Block+Chapter.
Notice that when you select a Block, it will automatically select the first Chapter from it. A block cannot contain anything else besides Chapters.
All Blocks, Chapters and Sections must have a name. Name is optional for components.
When you edit the content, you must always have at least 1 Block with 1 Chapter. The website will not let you delete content if you have less than required.
You can notice many buttons on the admin page. Everything in here is editable, therefore there are many ways you can interact with your blocks, chapters, sections and components.

components.subtitle: The Add Buttons
components.text: There are 4 different Add buttons available. You can add Blocks and Chapters from the menu on the left. You can add Sections to a Page through the Add Section button at the bottom of the page, or the Add New Section button on the right-side menu.
You can add components with the Add Component button. Since components must belong to a Section, every Section comes equipped with this button at the bottom of the Section.

components.subtitle: The Colored Borders
components.text: There are coloured borders displayed for Sections and Components. Sections have a blue border, and Components have a red border. This is so you can easily identify which component and section you are currently editing.
Notice that components(red borders) are encapsulated in sections(blue borders). You must understand this hierarchy before proceeding forward.
Blocks contain chapters, which contain sections, which contain components.

components.subtitle: The Collapse Button
components.text: Sections and Components can get fairly big in size, making it hard to navigate your page. These two elements come equipped with a Collapse button at the beginning. Clicking this will collapse the contents of the element, making the page shorter. It is good practice to collapse Sections that you have finished editing, and only leave the Section you are currently working on uncollapsed.

components.subtitle: Move and Delete Widgets
components.text: Every element has these widgets. It's a group of three buttons that can move the element up or down in the hierarchy, or delete it. You can easily change the order of your elements with these buttons, or delete an element. You will be prompted to accept when you try to delete something. They look something like this:

Add new Block
button.
You can change the order of the blocks using the and buttons. You can delete a block by pressing the
All of these actions are reversible from the Undo Stack

Chapters are parts of a block. You can see them listed on the left hand side menu. When you click on a block, you see all the chapters inside that block. You can add a new chapter by clicking on the
Add new Chapter
button. The chapter is added in the current active block.
You can change the order of the chapters within a block by using the and buttons. You can delete a chapter by pressing the
All of these actions are reversible from the Undo Stack

Sections are the main elements of a chapter (a page). Sections also appear on the right-side menu for quick navigation (their name is displayed there). You can add a new section by clicking on the
Add new Section
button available on the right-side menu.

You can also add sections from the
Add Section
button avaiable at the bottom of the page.
You can change the order of the sections within a page using the and buttons. You can delete a section by pressing the
All of these actions are reversible from the Undo Stack

Components are everything else on the page. They have a red border. Every section of the page is made of components. There are several types of components, like image, text, video, quote, reference etc. You can add a new component by clicking on the
Add Component
button available at the bottom of every section.
You can change the order of the components within a section using the and buttons. You can delete a component by pressing the
All of these actions are reversible from the Undo Stack
Once you access a chapter (a page), you will see all the elements of the page exposed. Most elements will have this icon on the top-left or next to their name.
Clicking on the icon will open an interface on the right side which lets you edit the corresponding element.

Blocks and chapters only have a name property. There is no button on the navigation menu on the left-hand side, simply because it was obscuring the names too much. To change the name of a block or a chapter, first you must access the chapter page, and at the top of the page you will see the block name with the icon next to it and underneath there is the chapter name with the icon next to it. Accessing the interface for the block or chapter will let you change their name.

Sections are the parts of the page with blue borders. They contain components, but they also have a name property which is mandatory, and a checkbox property for drawing a horizontal line at the end of the section. The icon lets you access the section interface to edit these two properties. It is situated in the top-left corner of the section, which is enclosed in blue borders.
Each component also comes equipped with the icon which is situated in the top-left corner. Just a reminder, components are enclosed in red borders.
Components are more complex, they contain various properties depending on the type. We will not go in-depth here about each component, we will talk about what properties all components share.

When you open the interface for a component, you will see three tabs. The first tab is called Component Basics and here you can edit the subtitle of the component and the checkbox property that draws a horizontal line at the end of the component.
The next tab is called Component Type. Here you can change the type of the component, if you are not happy with the type you chose when you created it.

The last tab is custom, based on what type you selected for the component. It is usually named {{Type}} Options. Here you can edit all the various properties of a specific component type. You can find more information on component types and their properties at this link.
On the far-right side of the page, you can see this button:
Most of your actions while editing are registered in this stack. You can see your previous actions by clicking the button.

Each of these actions gives you a brief description about where the change was made ( which block, chapter, section and component) and also displays an icon to show what type of action was made ( delete, move, add, edit). Each entry has an UNDO button that allows you to revert the state of your document back to how it was before that change.

When you click UNDO, you are reverting back the document to how it was before that change. That means that if you UNDO the 6th element in the stack, you will also lose the changes made in the 5 elements above. Think of this as hitting CTRL + Z on a windows machine. It reverts your previous change, but in order to revert back to the 6th previous change you made, you have to undo the 5 before as well.

Learn how to download your data after you made changes.

sections.subtitle: Download you data after making changes

components.text: This section only applies to you if your website is on a cloud server like Heroku where you cannot access your data. If you have your website on a local server, then whenever you press the 'Save Changes' button, your data is automatically saved in the folder called Data at the location of your website folder.
You have made some changes, added some content and pressed the Save Changes button in the top-right part of the page. Congratulations!! But what exactly happens to your data?

All data is stored in some files in the website folder. These files are grouped in a folder called 'Data'. If your website is on a cloud server, then you don't have access to the newly updated data straight away.
You can choose to download the data at any time using the Download Data button in the main admin interface. Clicking this will give you a data.zip file, which contains all your data in JSON format

It is always good practice to do this, because you will have a back-up of your data before making changes. If anything goes bad in your new update, or you go in a frenzy and start deleting everything, then you can recover from these mistakes if you have a back up of your data.
In the next chapter, we will talk about how to you use github to store your data and all the history of your different versions of data and how to upload a new version of data to your cloud website.

chapters.name: Using github to save your changes

components.text:
Github is, at its core, a collaboration tool. It makes open-source projects much easier to maintain. One of its features is version control. 
What this means is that you can at any time revert your files back to a previous state. With this capability, Github becomes a great place to store files that you continuously update. This way, you will have access to all versions of your files, between updates.

Whenever you click the Save Changes button, you are creating a new version of your data. If you want to never lose this data and always have access to all the different versions, then you should use github to store it.

sections.subtitle: How to save your changes to github

components.text: You can choose to download the data at any time using the Download Data button in the main admin interface. Clicking this will give you a data.zip file, which contains all your data in JSON format. You should unzip the file, and save the folder data somewhere on your computer.

list_elements.text: Go to your github page and select the repository containing your website.
Press the Upload files button
Select choose your files
Navigate to where you have saved your data folder and drag the entire folder to the github page. The upload will take several seconds depending on your connection speed.

You can add a commit message and commit description to identify this version later. It can be something related to what you added. For example if you added a new chapter, you can specify 'Added |chapter name|'. These are optional.
Press the Commit changes button.

This will take a bit of time to complete, usually less than a minute. You will then be returned to your repository page. Nothing seemed to have happened, but if you press the commits button, you will see that the version of your folder has been saved.

components.text: If you make any changes to the data folder locally and you want them to show up in the heroku website, you will have to re-upload your website to heroku. To do that, simply follow the steps in the Using heroku section, after you have saved your changes to your github repository.

In this block, we will go over all the available components you can use to build your pages. There is a variety of elements you can add to your page, from paragraphs, images and videos to links, lists, references and quizzes.
We will explore each component in detail, give you an example of how to use the related form elements for each one, and show you what to expect from each component in terms of appearance.

Help you get familiar with the form looks  and controls.

components.text: This is the most common component you will use, so it is important to understand how to use it properly.

Wherever you see text, there's probably a paragraph component involved. Paragraphs are the main tool used for writing information. You can embed links in paragraphs, like this Google link, and you can add a background to a paragraph, like the paragraph below.
This is a paragraph with background. This paragraph also has a separator drawn below.
components.subtitle: This is a paragraph subtitle

components.text: If you click the icon on a paragraph component, you will see the following options.

The Component Basics and Component Type are 2 form sections that you will see in every component form. The first one allows you to change the subtitle of the component and whether to draw a separator line at the end of it, the second one allows you to change the type of the component. We will not cover these two sections in the following chapters, because they are the same for all components. What changes from component to component is the last form section.

components.subtitle: Text, background and links
components.text: The big text area is where you will enter the text that will be displayed. The checkbox that says Emphasize text will add a background to the paragraph. The button Embed Links will open some more options for you to describe what words you want to be hyperlinked and what is the link.

The form above is what you will see after clicking the Embed Links button. It is fairly straight-forward. In the first entry you have to enter the text to be hyper-linked, and the second entry is for the actual link.
You can add multiple links. Simply press the Add Link button and another Link entry will appear. The order of your links doesn't matter.

list_elements.text: A link applies to all occurences of the typed text. If you link the word 'this', then it will link all occurences of the word this. Try to link only meaningful patters. Instead of this, you can have 'at this github link' and link the entire pattern.
You can change the order of your links, but that has no effect. To delete a link, simply press the trash can icon associated with each link.

components.text: Paragraphs support HTML code. The website comes equipped with Bootstrap 4 and Font Awesome 4. You can use their documentation to find out how to insert icons and how to edit the display of text. You can include awesome icons like this check mark.

The list is simply a collection of paragraphs. See this tutorial to find out about how to edit paragraphs. The order of your paragraphs matters in this case and you can edit them by using the
buttons.

components.text: An empty list only comes with one button: Add list entry . Pressing the button will add the first paragraph to your list. You can add multiple paragraphs by pressing the Add another button.

The Link(s) component is a list of links. They are surrounded by a gray border. Use this component when you want to include some links that don't necesarily belong in a paragraph. It's a good component for grouping up together external related resources.

This is a simple form. It comes with a Add Link button. Each link has an entry for the text to be displayed and an entry for the actual URL. The order of the links affects the order they are displayed in and you can change that order by using the corresponding
buttons.
The Image component lets you upload an image to the server for display. The form is very simple, it consists of an Add Image button.
If the image name shows up written in red, then the image has been uploaded. Sometimes, you will have to save your form before seeing the image.

There are several things to think about when uploading a single image. First of all, the size in memory of the image. The form will not allow you to upload an image that is more than 80kb in size. Images have to be loaded by the browser when the page containing it is accessed. Images take a long time to load if they are too big, this restriction is here to make sure that the website still performs correctly even when it contains many images.

Another thing to think about is image width and height. The website does not enforce any width or height on your image, which means that you can include any type of image. It is important to think about how your image scales with screen size. I recommend for your images to have less then 600px width, more than that will make the image overflow from the edges of the containing document.

The Document component is used to group and link documents (PDF or docx). You can either provide a URL that links to an online document, or you can upload your own document to the server. There is no restriction on the size of your document, but it has to be one of the following : .PDF .DOCX .DOC
The component can hold multiple documents, so you will again have the common buttons for Add entry and Add another

You can change the order of the documents using the
buttons on the corresponding elements.

The form for a single document contains an entry for the label (text to be displayed) and an entry for a URL. If you are uploading a file, click the icon, which will let you choose a document from your local computer
If you are simply linking to a document online, enter the URL of the document in the second box.

This warning lets you know that a file with this name already exists on the server. This warning only happens when you try to upload a file. It shouldn't be an issue if you are reusing a file. You should be careful when trying to upload a file that has different content than the one with the same name on the server. The new file will replace the old file, and the old file will no longer be available.

The video component allows you to link to an external video resource. You are not allowed to upload videos. If you have to upload videos, you should consider Youtube, they are a really good provider for this service.
In the video form, you have a field to enter a URL. You must enter a video resource URL here. In the case of youtube, you can enter any youtube URL.
If you are entering another video URL, maybe from your own university media library, make sure to include the URL which contains only the video. ( ask for the embed URL).

If you enter a Youtube link, the form will automatically detect a suitable thumbnail for it.
If you provide another resource, then you will have to upload your thumbnail manually.
Simlpy press the Add Image button to add a thumbnail image for your video. Notice that the help text specifies that the thumbnail image cannot be more than 20kb and to resize it to 200x113 px.
The video carousel is just a collection of videos. Press the Add Video button to add a Video to your list. Each Video needs to have a title. A video carousel looks like this:

components.text: In this block, we will talk about editing the Main Page. Although it contains components which have been discussed previously, there are some things to clarify about what you can and can't edit on the front page of the website.

list_elements.text: Discuss what the main page contains.
Learn how to change the background images and other various elements of the front page.

components.text: I have exposed almost everything on the front page for you to be able to edit. In order to access this exposed content, simply go to the main admin interface and choose Main Page Content .
We will go over each section and talk about what you can edit and what you cannot.

The first section allows you to edit the Introduction Video. You can change the thumbnail and the video link. Notice that you cannot add a subtitle to this component. The subtitle is not displayed. Apart from that, the interface looks very similar to the Video element discussed before.

The main page contains a screen where various quotes show up. You can edit these quotes from this section. Clicking the icon will expose the quotes. You can add, remove or change the order of the quotes using the
and the Add Quote buttons.
Each quote contains a text field, an Author field and a Year field. They are pretty straightforward.

Notice that you can't delete the entire section. You need to have the section, but you can delete all quotes if you don't want them to show up. You can also just write anything else here, not necessarily quotes. The Author and Year fields are optional.
The main paragraph represents the text displayed in the purple box on the front page. You can edit that text from the Main Paragraph section.

The form resembles the Alert form discussed before. The only thing you can edit is the text. the element is displayed as an Alert box in the admin interface, but this doesn't have any influence to how the element is displayed on the front page.
You cannot delete this section. The main paragraph of the front page must exist.

In the main page footer, you can see a list of contact details, with telephone numbers and e-mails. You can use this section to edit those details, add as many telephone numbers and e-mails as you want. The form looks exactly like the previously discussed Contact Information form.
The section comes with the default name of Disabilities Team, but you can change this by editing the section.

Focusing on the main page footer now, you can see two sections there called Affiliations and Useful Sites. These sections contain images that link to a specific website when clicked. It is a good place to put external resources and affiliations.

You can add as many affiliations and useful sites as you want, or you can delete the components. The form is similar to the Image form, but you have to add a URL as well which will be the destination link when the user clicks the image.

The last two sections are called background_up and background_down. These represent the two background images on the main page. You can upload other images if you want, and the 80KB is lifted in this case and you can upload images with maximum size of 280KB. These images will be stretched to fill the space, so make sure to play with your image size before uploading. As a guideline, the current background images have a size of 968 x 644 pixels.
You can have the same image in both backgrounds. You will have to upload the same file in both sections.
